Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.raw_text: Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438 Mass. 317, 319–20 (2002).
Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant acted through its officers, employees, agents, and/or servants, all of whom were acting within the course and scope of their employment or agency, so as to render Defendant vicariously liable under the doctrine of respondeat superior.
Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.case_name: Dias v. Brigham Medical Associates, Inc.
Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.support_reasoning: The opinion directly addresses vicarious liability of a medical practice group for the acts of its physician-employee and explains that, once an employer-employee relationship is established, traditional respondeat superior applies to make the employer liable for torts committed within the scope of employment. Although the court remands because of a factual dispute over whether the doctor was acting within the scope of his BMA employment at the precise time of treatment, it clearly affirms that an employer is vicariously liable for its employees’ torts committed in the scope of employment, which matches the proposition’s statement of respondeat superior liability through officers, employees, and agents. The case is thus good authority for the general proposition of vicarious liability, contingent on proof of scope of employment.
Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.relevant_excerpt: To prevail against BMA, the plaintiffs need only establish that (1) at the time of the alleged negligence Dr. Schlitzer was an employee of BMA, and (2) the alleged negligent treatment of the plaintiff occurred within the scope of Dr. Schlitzer’s employment by BMA. Once employment is established, the only remaining issue is whether he was working for BMA at the time of the alleged negligent treatment, i.e., whether his treatment of the plaintiff was within the scope of his employment by BMA. This comports with traditional agency law that ‘[a]n employer is liable for torts committed by employees while acting in the scope of their employment.’

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19 and 19A.proposition: This Court has subject‑matter jurisdiction over this civil action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19 and 19A, because the amount in controversy is within the jurisdictional limits of the District Court Department.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2, and 8.proposition: Venue is proper in the Brockton District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2, and 8, because the cause of action arose in Brockton, Plymouth County, Massachusetts, and Defendant’s principal place of business and the relevant premises are located in Brockton.

Irwin v. Ware, 392 Mass. 745, 756\u20135.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a person or entity that undertakes the supervision and care of a child owes that child a duty of reasonable care to protect him from reasonably foreseeable harms.
Irwin v. Ware, 392 Mass. 745, 756\u20135.support_reasoning: The court expressly discusses when a duty to protect others from third‑party misconduct arises based on a “special relationship,” and then cites, as an example, that a group child-care facility has a duty to control the acts of delinquent children (Eldredge v. Kamp Kachess Youth Serv., Inc.). It further states that duties to prevent harm caused by third persons can rest on such relationships, including in child-care contexts, thereby endorsing the principle that one who undertakes supervision and care of a child owes a duty of reasonable care to protect from foreseeable harms. Although the case involves police and drunk driving, its discussion of special relationships clearly embraces custodial supervision of children as giving rise to such a duty.
Irwin v. Ware, 392 Mass. 745, 756\u20135.relevant_excerpt: “Furthermore, many cases have established that liability may arise solely from the violation of an affirmative duty to act with reasonable care to prevent harm to another caused by a third person. See, e.g., … Eldredge v. Kamp Kachess Youth Serv., Inc., 90 Wash.2d 402, 408 (1978) (group child care facility's duty to control acts of delinquent children). … Such a duty to prevent harm to another caused by a third person has been recognized for public employees as well as private individuals.”

Remy v. MacDonald, 440 Mass. 675, 677\u2.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a person or entity that undertakes the supervision and care of a child owes that child a duty of reasonable care to protect him from reasonably foreseeable harms.
Remy v. MacDonald, 440 Mass. 675, 677\u2.support_reasoning: The case is about whether a fetus/child can sue her mother for prenatal negligence, and the court ultimately holds there is no duty of care owed by a pregnant woman to her unborn child for unintentional prenatal injuries. It does not discuss the general Massachusetts rule for those who undertake supervision and care of a child, nor does it articulate a duty of reasonable care arising from such an undertaking. Instead, it carves out an exception to the general duty of care in the specific mother–fetus context, so it does not support the cited proposition.
Remy v. MacDonald, 440 Mass. 675, 677\u2.relevant_excerpt: “We must decide whether a pregnant woman owes a legal duty of care to her unborn child to refrain from negligent conduct that may result in physical harm to that child. If no such duty exists, a claim of negligence cannot be brought… There is nothing in our statutes or case law, however, that addresses the situation before us.… We conclude that there are inherent and important differences between a fetus, in utero, and a child already born, that permits a bright line to be drawn around the zone of potential tort liability of one who is still biologically joined to an injured plaintiff.”

Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.raw_text: Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 47, 52–54 (1983)
Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.proposition: Defendant, by operating an after‑school program, accepting custody of L.J., inviting him onto its premises, and representing that children would be supervised at all times in the gym, undertook a duty to exercise reasonable care in the supervision, protection, and control of children in its charge, including L.J.
Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.support_reasoning: The provided text is a dissent in Mullins v. Pine Manor College and is focused entirely on proximate cause and foreseeability in the context of campus security and rape; it does not involve an after‑school program, acceptance of custody of a child, or a duty to supervise children. While the majority opinion in Mullins does recognize a college’s duty to exercise reasonable care for the safety of its students, nothing in this excerpt addresses or establishes a duty arising from operating an after‑school program or supervising children in a gym. Thus, this citation, as presented, does not support the specific proposition claimed.
Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.relevant_excerpt: The plaintiff had the burden of proving “that the defendant[s] took a risk with respect to the plaintiff’s safety that a person of ordinary prudence would not have taken, and that the plaintiff suffered a resulting injury that was within the foreseeable risk.” Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., 385 Mass. 323, 330 (1982). Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc., 355 Mass. 450, 454 (1969).

Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2.proposition: Defendant, by operating an after‑school program, accepting custody of L.J., inviting him onto its premises, and representing that children would be supervised at all times in the gym, undertook a duty to exercise reasonable care in the supervision, protection, and control of children in its charge, including L.J.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2.support_reasoning: The case has nothing to do with an after‑school program, custodial care of children, or a duty to supervise children. It concerns a property owner’s potential negligence and statutory liability for injuries to adult workers caused by collapsing scaffolding, and the court ultimately does not even reach the duty question because plaintiffs failed on causation. Thus, it provides no authority for the proposition that operating an after‑school program and accepting custody of a child creates a duty to use reasonable care in supervision and protection of children.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2.relevant_excerpt: "The motion judge found that the plaintiffs had not shown the requisite control necessary to impose a duty on the defendant. Because the plaintiffs have failed to meet their burden on the issue of causation, we need not decide whether they presented sufficient evidence to show that the defendant owed a duty of care to them sufficient to survive the defendant’s motion for summary judgment."

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: As a possessor of land open to invitees, Defendant owed L.J. the duty to use reasonable care to keep the premises in a reasonably safe condition and to protect him against foreseeable risks created by the conduct of third persons on the premises.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708\u2.proposition: As a possessor of land open to invitees, Defendant owed L.J. the duty to use reasonable care to keep the premises in a reasonably safe condition and to protect him against foreseeable risks created by the conduct of third persons on the premises.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708\u2.support_reasoning: The provided excerpt is a concurrence by Justice Kaplan criticizing the continued use of rigid status-based classifications (trespasser/licensee/invitee). It does not discuss, articulate, or apply a specific duty of reasonable care owed by a possessor of land to invitees regarding third-party conduct. While the main Mounsey opinion does reform landowner duties, this particular cited portion (363 Mass. 693, 708–09, Kaplan, J., concurring) does not clearly establish the specific duty described in the proposition.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708\u2.relevant_excerpt: "The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a 'licensee' rather than an 'invitee,' or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that 'trespassers' stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential."

Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.proposition: As a possessor of land open to invitees, Defendant owed L.J. the duty to use reasonable care to keep the premises in a reasonably safe condition and to protect him against foreseeable risks created by the conduct of third persons on the premises.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.support_reasoning: The court expressly states the general common-law duty of an owner or possessor of land to lawful visitors: to use reasonable care, maintain the premises in reasonably safe condition, and warn of dangers. Although the case ultimately holds there is no duty to alter the adjacent state highway, the opinion clearly affirms the underlying duty principle for possessors of land open to invitees, including protection against unreasonable and foreseeable risks (which can include risks involving third persons). Thus, it supports the stated proposition as a matter of general duty doctrine.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.relevant_excerpt: “It is well established that an owner or possessor of land owes a common law duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors. Sullivan v. Brookline, 416 Mass. 825, 827 (1994), citing Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1973). This duty includes an obligation to maintain the premises in reasonably safe condition and to warn visitors of any unreasonable dangers of which the landowner is aware or reasonably should be aware.”

Foster v. The Loft, Inc., 26 Mass. App..raw_text: Foster v. The Loft, Inc., 26 Mass. App. Ct. 289, 290–92 (1988)
Foster v. The Loft, Inc., 26 Mass. App..proposition: Defendant further had a duty to adequately hire, train, supervise, and oversee its staff members to ensure that they exercised reasonable care in supervising children.
Foster v. The Loft, Inc., 26 Mass. App..support_reasoning: The case recognizes and applies the doctrines of negligent hiring and negligent retention, but it frames the duty as one to exercise reasonable care in the selection and retention of employees who interact with the public, not as a separate, broader duty to adequately hire, train, supervise, and oversee staff to ensure reasonable care in supervising children. The opinion involves a bar patron injured by a bartender, not the supervision of children, and it does not discuss any specific duty to train or supervise employees beyond hiring/retention decisions. Thus it does not support the proposition as stated.
Foster v. The Loft, Inc., 26 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: “The doctrine states that an employer whose employees are brought in contact with members of the public in the course of the employer’s business has a duty to exercise reasonable care in the selection and retention of his employees. ‘An employer must use due care to avoid the selection or retention of an employee whom he knows or should know is a person unworthy, by habits, temperament, or nature, to deal with the persons invited to the premises by the employer.’… It is the negligent retention aspect of the doctrine that formed the basis of the jury’s verdict against the defendant.”

Jorgensen v. Mass. Port Auth., 905 F.2d.raw_text: Jorgensen v. Mass. Port Auth., 905 F.2d 515, 523 (1st Cir. 1990)
Jorgensen v. Mass. Port Auth., 905 F.2d.proposition: Had Defendant exercised reasonable care—by maintaining adequate staffing, enforcing its own supervision representations, actively supervising the children, and promptly stopping the dangerous tackling game—the incident and resulting injury to L.J. would not have occurred.
Jorgensen v. Mass. Port Auth., 905 F.2d.case_name: Lisa Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Authority, Appeal of Donald Hertzfeldt and Peter Langley
Jorgensen v. Mass. Port Auth., 905 F.2d.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns ordinary negligence, reasonable care in supervision, and causation in a child‑injury context (staffing, supervision, stopping a dangerous game). Jorgensen deals with whether reputation damages are recoverable in an ordinary negligence action and, more specifically, with foreseeability and proximate cause of reputational and economic harm to airline pilots after an airport accident. It does not address duties of supervision, staffing, or the causal link between active supervision and prevention of physical injury to a child, so it does not provide authority for the stated proposition.
Jorgensen v. Mass. Port Auth., 905 F.2d.relevant_excerpt: "In any negligence cause of action, there are four elements on which plaintiffs must adduce adequate evidence to prevail. Plaintiffs must show: (1) a legal duty owed by defendant to plaintiff; (2) a breach of that duty; (3) proximate or legal cause; and (4) actual damage or injury.... The existence of a duty and the breach of that duty are not at issue here... Proximate cause, however, is very much at issue."

Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.raw_text: Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc., 423 Mass. 637, 640–41 (1996)
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.proposition: The harm suffered by L.J. was the kind of harm that made Defendant’s negligence unreasonable and was within the scope of the foreseeable risks created by Defendant’s failure to supervise and control the children in its care.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.support_reasoning: The concurrence states that the plaintiff’s injuries were not within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence. The claimed proposition asserts the opposite: that the harm was the kind of harm that made the negligence unreasonable and was within the scope of foreseeable risks. Thus, this opinion contradicts rather than supports the cited proposition.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.relevant_excerpt: “I concur in the view that ‘[t]he facts would not warrant a jury’s finding that the plaintiff’s injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence.’ Ante at 640-641.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85L.proposition: Plaintiff, as L.J.’s parent and guardian, has incurred and become legally obligated to pay medical expenses for L.J.’s care and treatment in an approximate amount of $5,000 to date, and may incur additional reasonable medical expenses in the future.

McGuiggan v. New England Tel. & Tel. Co..raw_text: McGuiggan v. New England Tel. & Tel. Co., 398 Mass. 152, 157–58 (1986)
McGuiggan v. New England Tel. & Tel. Co..proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover on behalf of L.J. for all past and future pain and suffering, emotional distress, and loss of enjoyment of life, and to recover for all reasonable and necessary medical expenses incurred as a result of Defendant’s negligence.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover on behalf of L.J. for all past and future pain and suffering, emotional distress, and loss of enjoyment of life, and to recover for all reasonable and necessary medical expenses incurred as a result of Defendant’s negligence.

G.L. c. 261.proposition: Costs of this action as permitted by G.L. c. 261 and the Massachusetts Rules of Civil Procedure;

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 60 and Mass. R. Civ. P. 38, Plaintiff demands a trial by jury on all issues so triable.
